Package mz

Interface QuickInterface<T extends Comparable>

Type Parameters:
T - setting of a type based on which the elements can be sorted.
All Superinterfaces:
Sort<T>, SortSwap<T>
All Known Subinterfaces:
Intro<T>, IntroDPQ<T>
All Known Implementing Classes:
DualPivotQuick, IntroAnother, IntroBatcherOddEvenMerge, IntroBubble, IntroCocktail, IntroComb, IntroDoubleSelection, IntroDPQAnother, IntroDPQBatcherOddEvenMerge, IntroDPQBubble, IntroDPQCocktail, IntroDPQComb, IntroDPQDoubleSelection, IntroDPQDualPivotQuick, IntroDPQGnome, IntroDPQHeap, IntroDPQInsertion, IntroDPQMerge, IntroDPQMerge3, IntroDPQMergeInPlace, IntroDPQMergeInsertion, IntroDPQOddEven, IntroDPQOddEvenMerge, IntroDPQQuick, IntroDPQQuick3, IntroDPQSelection, IntroDPQShell, IntroDPQSmoothHeap, IntroDPQStableQuick, IntroDPQTernaryHeap, IntroDPQTim, IntroDPQWeakHeap, IntroDPQWeaveMerge, IntroDPQWiki, IntroDualPivotQuick, IntroGnome, IntroHeap, IntroInsertion, IntroMerge, IntroMerge3, IntroMergeInPlace, IntroMergeInsertion, IntroOddEven, IntroOddEvenMerge, IntroQuick, IntroQuick3, IntroSelection, IntroShell, IntroSmoothHeap, IntroStableQuick, IntroTernaryHeap, IntroTim, IntroWeakHeap, IntroWeaveMerge, IntroWiki, Quick, Quick3, StableQuick
public interface QuickInterface<T extends Comparable> extends Sort<T>, SortSwap<T>
QuickInterface, containing the methods of Quick Sort to implement other classes.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

  • Method Details

    • quickInc

      default void quickInc(T[] array)
      Implementation of a quick sort algorithm for sorting the array of comparable objects in ascending order. The quickInc method follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of quicksort, recursively partitioning the array into smaller subarrays and sorting them individually. The base case of the recursion is when the subarray has only one element, in which case it is considered already sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • quickInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • quickDec

      default void quickDec(T[] array)
      Implementation of a quick sort algorithm for sorting the array of comparable objects in ascending order. The quickDec method follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of quicksort, recursively partitioning the array into smaller subarrays and sorting them individually. The base case of the recursion is when the subarray has only one element, in which case it is considered already sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • quickDec(Comparable[], int, int)

    • quickInc

      default void quickInc(T[] array, int left, int right)
      Implementation of a quick sort algorithm for sorting the array of comparable objects in ascending order. The quickInc method follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of quicksort, recursively partitioning the array into smaller subarrays and sorting them individually. The base case of the recursion is when the subarray has only one element, in which case it is considered already sorted.
      • The method quickInc takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices left and right that define the range of the subarray being sorted.
      • The first condition if (left < right) checks if the subarray has more than one element. If it does, the sorting continues; otherwise, the subarray is already sorted, and the method returns.
      • Inside the condition, the quickInc method is called to partition the array and obtain the partitionIndex, which represents the correct position of the pivot element after the partitioning.
      • The quickInc method is recursively called twice:
      • The first recursive call sorts the left partition of the array by calling quickInc with left as the start index and (partitionIndex - 1) as the end index.
      • The second recursive call sorts the right partition of the array by calling quickInc with (partitionIndex + 1) as the start index and right as the end index.
      • This process is repeated until the entire array is sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:
      • partitionInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • quickDec

      default void quickDec(T[] array, int left, int right)
      Implementation of a quick sort algorithm for sorting the array of comparable objects in ascending order. The quickDec method follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of quicksort, recursively partitioning the array into smaller subarrays and sorting them individually. The base case of the recursion is when the subarray has only one element, in which case it is considered already sorted.
      • The method quickDec takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices left and right that define the range of the subarray being sorted.
      • The first condition if (left < right) checks if the subarray has more than one element. If it does, the sorting continues; otherwise, the subarray is already sorted, and the method returns.
      • Inside the condition, the quickDec method is called to partition the array and obtain the partitionIndex, which represents the correct position of the pivot element after the partitioning.
      • The quickDec method is recursively called twice:
      • The first recursive call sorts the left partition of the array by calling quickDec with left as the start index and (partitionIndex - 1) as the end index.
      • The second recursive call sorts the right partition of the array by calling quickDec with (partitionIndex + 1) as the start index and right as the end index.
      • This process is repeated until the entire array is sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:
      • partitionDec(Comparable[], int, int)

    • partitionInc

      default int partitionInc(T[] array, int left, int right)
      Provided seems to be an implementation of the partitioning step of the quicksort algorithm. It partitions an array into two parts, one with elements smaller than a pivot and another with elements greater than or equal to the pivot.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method partitionInc takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices left and right that define the range of the subarray being partitioned. It returns the index of the pivot element after the partitioning is done.
      • The pivot element is chosen as array[right], which is the last element of the subarray.
      • The variable i is initialized to (left - 1). It will keep track of the boundary between the elements smaller than the pivot and those greater than or equal to the pivot.
      • A loop is executed from left to (right - 1) to iterate over the elements of the subarray.
      • Inside the loop, each element array[j] is compared to the pivot using the compareTo method of Comparable. If the element is smaller than the pivot, the following steps are executed:
      • i is incremented by 1 to expand the smaller elements region.
      • The swap method is called to swap array[i] and array[j], moving the smaller element to the left.
      • After the loop, the pivot element is moved to its correct position by swapping it with array[i + 1]. This ensures that all elements to the left of array[i + 1] are smaller than or equal to the pivot, and all elements to the right are greater than the pivot.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      Returns:
      index of the pivot element.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • partitionDec

      default int partitionDec(T[] array, int left, int right)
      Provided seems to be an implementation of the partitioning step of the quicksort algorithm. It partitions an array into two parts, one with elements smaller than a pivot and another with elements greater than or equal to the pivot.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method partitionDec takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices left and right that define the range of the subarray being partitioned. It returns the index of the pivot element after the partitioning is done.
      • The pivot element is chosen as array[right], which is the last element of the subarray.
      • The variable i is initialized to (left - 1). It will keep track of the boundary between the elements smaller than the pivot and those greater than or equal to the pivot.
      • A loop is executed from left to (right - 1) to iterate over the elements of the subarray.
      • Inside the loop, each element array[j] is compared to the pivot using the compareTo method of Comparable. If the element is greater than the pivot, the following steps are executed:
      • i is incremented by 1 to expand the smaller elements region.
      • The swap method is called to swap array[i] and array[j], moving the smaller element to the left.
      • After the loop, the pivot element is moved to its correct position by swapping it with array[i + 1]. This ensures that all elements to the left of array[i + 1] are smaller than or equal to the pivot, and all elements to the right are greater than the pivot.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      Returns:
      the index of the pivot element.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • partitionDualInc

      default int[] partitionDualInc(T[] array, int left, int right)
      partitionDualInc It partitions an array of elements array between the indices left and right (inclusive) and returns an array of two integers representing the indices of the pivots after the partitioning.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The first step compares the elements at indices left and right and swaps them if the element at left is greater than the element at right. This ensures that the pivot1 (the leftmost pivot) is smaller than or equal to pivot2 (the rightmost pivot).
      • The variables newLeft, newRight, and selectIndex are initialized. newLeft points to the index after the pivot1, newRight points to the index before pivot2, and selectIndex starts from the index after the left pivot.
      • The algorithm enters a while loop that continues until selectIndex surpasses newRight.
      • Inside the loop, the algorithm checks if the element at selectIndex is smaller than pivot1. If it is, the element is swapped with the element at newLeft, and newLeft is incremented by 1.
      • If the element at selectIndex is not smaller than pivot1, the algorithm checks if it is greater than or equal to pivot2. If it is, the algorithm enters another loop that finds an element from the right side of the partition that is smaller than or equal to pivot2. This loop decrements newRight until it finds such an element or until selectIndex surpasses newRight.
      • Once the element is found, the element at selectIndex is swapped with the found element, and newRight is decremented by 1. Then, if the element at selectIndex is smaller than pivot1, the element is swapped with the element at newLeft, and newLeft is incremented by 1.
      • Finally, selectIndex is incremented by 1, and the while loop continues until selectIndex surpasses newRight.
      • After the loop finishes, the left pivot pivot1 is swapped with the element at newLeft - 1, and the right pivot pivot2 is swapped with the element at newRight + 1. This step puts the pivots in their correct positions.
      partitionDualInc The method returns an int array containing the indices of the pivots in the partitioned array, [newLeft, newRight].
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      Returns:
      the pivots in the partitioned array.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • partitionDualDec

      default int[] partitionDualDec(T[] array, int left, int right)
      partitionDualDec It partitions an array of elements array between the indices left and right (inclusive) and returns an array of two integers representing the indices of the pivots after the partitioning.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The first step compares the elements at indices left and right and swaps them if the element at left is greater than the element at right. This ensures that the pivot1 (the leftmost pivot) is smaller than or equal to pivot2 (the rightmost pivot).
      • The variables newLeft, newRight, and selectIndex are initialized. newLeft points to the index after the pivot1, newRight points to the index before pivot2, and selectIndex starts from the index after the left pivot.
      • The algorithm enters a while loop that continues until selectIndex surpasses newRight.
      • Inside the loop, the algorithm checks if the element at selectIndex is greater than pivot1. If it is, the element is swapped with the element at newLeft, and newLeft is incremented by 1.
      • If the element at selectIndex is not greater than pivot1, the algorithm checks if it is smaller than or equal to pivot2. If it is, the algorithm enters another loop that finds an element from the right side of the partition that is greater than or equal to pivot2. This loop decrements newRight until it finds such an element or until selectIndex surpasses newRight.
      • Once the element is found, the element at selectIndex is swapped with the found element, and newRight is decremented by 1. Then, if the element at selectIndex is greater than pivot1, the element is swapped with the element at newLeft, and newLeft is incremented by 1.
      • Finally, selectIndex is incremented by 1, and the while loop continues until selectIndex surpasses newRight.
      • After the loop finishes, the left pivot pivot1 is swapped with the element at newLeft - 1, and the right pivot pivot2 is swapped with the element at newRight + 1. This step puts the pivots in their correct positions.
      partitionDualDec The method returns an int array containing the indices of the pivots in the partitioned array, [newLeft, newRight].
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      Returns:
      the pivots in the partitioned array.
      See Also:
